>>65714bbe-0242-4a63-aab0-f3c2942c6196
>Should everything wait until the owner's node gets the data and updates something?
No. The system is decentralized.
When you publish the data you publish it directly to other peers.

There is currently a whitelist of allowed mimetypes though:
https://gitgud.io/mcdev/Millchan/blob/master/js/millchan/00_config.coffee#L32

So if you try post something outside of the whitelist it won't work.

If you need a new mimetype to be added to the whitelist then ask in this thread.

>>2755ab64-4098-4e74-b76b-8d13d4f4f142
Fixed the problem with /lit/.
I was assuming the size of the user address is constant (with length 34) but apparently that's not the case.

$ for w in $(ls -d */ | cut -d'/' -f1); do echo ${#w}; done | sort | uniq -c
      1 33
     19 34

On 0ch's data dir:
     48 33
   1165 34

So it should be safe with {33,34} but I changed to {32,34} just in case.

>>2755ab64-4098-4e74-b76b-8d13d4f4f142
>Neither I can see the image in the only post in /file/
It works in my machine.
All media files are defined as optional in content.json.
They will only be downloaded by other peers on request.
That means if someone posts something and then stops seeding before anyone else requests it, then it will fail to load for everyone else that tries to load it (that's what's happening with the Saber thread on /a/ for instance).

Images are being loaded lazily now.
This mitigates the browser being  overwhelmed with requests in pages with many files.

>>17dbf210-9bfd-4ba8-82e3-56662587f9e6
>waterfox just has it trying to load for a few minutes before giving me this
That's the expected behavior.
It's the CSS for an onerror event.

But before that, while the image is loading, it can affect the loading of all other images as well.

Images that have already been downloaded will be displayed as "loading" until the image that is ''hanging'' triggers an onerror event.
After that happens the other images will proceed to load normally.

>>aa166ba5-0c50-4756-9481-3c36d65d7cdf
>tor, i2p
>plausible deniability
I'm not sure what you mean.
The routing protocol in those protects the identity of the user requesting the files but after fetching the content it can (will in most cases) be cached unencrypted in the users' hard drive.

But you're right about Freenet.
It does have security options that allow users to define what will be stored in their disks and how safe should the storage be.
Nevertheless, they still '''strongly''' recommend people to only run Freenet in an encrypted environment.
So, that's also the advice I would give to anyone planning to run any of these applications.

>>22c8c841-1601-47f1-8a47-d19d355b8ae5
I think you're underestimating a little bit how much forensic information can still be gathered from those applications even after the user has set the cache size to zero.
Otherwise that would be no demand for things like Whonix and Tails.

But I agree with you that there are things that could be done to enhance the security of ZeroNet.
Based on the posts I've seen, it doesn't look it's one of their priorities in the developers minds right now though.

>i can't honestly say if i think safely encrypting the data directory should be ZN's job, or if it's best left to individual users
Personally I don't think it should be ZeroNet's job to do that.
It would increase the complexity and the attack surface of ZN's code and it would probably take years to reach anywhere near the same level of maturity of other software that could be used to encrypt the hard drive itself instead.

Also, this seems relevant to this topic.
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/252

>kills the spoiler image generation
I think you mean the thumbnail image generation since the spoiler image is just a static required file.
But you're right about the white image being related with the canvas fingerprint.

Tor displays the fingerprint prompt if the browser calls toDataURL of a canvas element.
https://gitgud.io/mcdev/Millchan/blob/51e6b3df3c0ef61c52f8174c2b17267ed7aa3025/js/millchan/00_vue.coffee#L277

A white image is returned if the user does not allow the browser to access the data in the canvas element.

I'm not considering a bug because all the client-side thumbnail generation methods I've seen so far rely on the browser being able to access the data in the canvas element.

Unfortunately, there are currently no alternatives for that.
It would be possible to add a notification explaining that that would be displayed the first time an user tries to upload an image though.

This is the number of threads the browser creates in the catalog.
[code]
config.max_pages * config.threads_per_page
[/code]
These are the current values of these variables
[code]
@max_pages = 15
@threads_per_page = 10
[/code]
So threads that exceed that limit will not appear in the catalog but they can still be accessed/bumped by the people who still have the link to them.
Posts/threads will only "disappear" is the user who posted manually deletes it from his data.json file or if everyone else stops seeding it.

>>0a91eebb-427a-46ad-a2d0-87b1690ee0ee
>hiding a board doesn't stop you from seeding it
If you have downloaded a file that you do not want to seed you can easily click the download manager and exclude it from your node.
Blacklisting a board will '''not''' automatically do that for you but it will prevent all the future uploads in a given board from being rendered and hence downloaded for you unless you explicitly visit the board again or if you have enabled "Help download and distribute all files", which is something I would advice against if you cannot actively monitor the content you're seeding.

In this case, the only thing that you will still be seeding are the text in the user's content.json and data.json files, which should be avoided after the integration with the Mute plugin.
If that's still a problem to you, you can just locally remove read/write permissions for any directory of users you are concerned about it.

I like ZeroNet's philosophy of allowing users to control what they see and seed, and I plan to implement as many tools are possible to make something similar here, making the process as simple and as transparent to the users as possible, but if you're looking for censorship in a global scale or for other people to babysit content for you, this might not be the perfect place for you.

By default, no user images are automatically downloaded to other nodes (and they will never be) and users can choose to stop seeding any file at any time.
I'm responsible for my own node as each user is responsible for his/her own.

If you're talking about moral responsibility, then the only responsibilities that I see for myself are related to give users the tools that they need to adequately protect themselves and that's what I intent to keep working on.

You should be able to '''mute''' users and board owners now.

==THIS WILL DELETE ALL THE LOCAL CONTENT THAT WAS DOWNLOADED FROM THAT USER INCLUDING HIS DATA.JSON FILE.==

If you're worried about seeding "bad text" this feature is for you.

I fail to see how using the Merger plugin would fix that problem.

>mute/blacklist features don't seem to behave as they should (at least for me?)
Unfortunately I suffer from the limitation known as not being able to read other people's minds.
Last I checked http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/12NPW6WLFBLVivNGqijcfktARobftfLFAN:dev:b79fce8b-df0d-4ab4-a89e-4c37585aa6d1#e0116499-6c11-4bcd-b3c3-216cd022b6a2 and https://gitgud.io/mcdev/Millchan/commit/ee9f7cfd2876eee736ba10aefedd80afbaaf51b1
fixed the problems related with deletion and the user can see the files being deleted in the console if the debug option is enabled in the user settings.
If there are still problems I have not been informed of them.

You're also overestimating how much control it is currently possible to have as a zite owner.
If someone enables the "Download and help distribute all files" feature content may be downloaded to the user's client without requiring any user interaction.
In this case, all current methods that would allow someone else to moderate the user's node and remove any questionable files that are being seeded require user interaction (i.e., browsing and execution a fileDete action generated from the Javascript API wrapper).

For me that virtually nullifies the point of using the Merger plugin since, ultimately, the end user is the only person who can keep his/her node safe and clean from anything that he doesn't want to seed.

We're about halfway through the season and I'm surprised the Isekai show is the only one I've dropped so far.

FranXX had a chaotic start but the other episodes were fairly entertaining albeit I've yet to see a likeable character in the cast.
The loli chess show doesn't have the right to be as enjoyable as it is.

The other comfy shows are still comfy.

>how are we supposed to handle spam without it?
The [M]ute button.
With two clicks you can remove all the posts that have been made by a spammer.

There are also limits that are imposed by the zite owner to limit the amount of content a user can share from a self-generated userID.

The only enhancement that I see being applied to this system in the future is an integration with a PoW algorithm to make it more expensive for spammers to generate new userIDs.
See: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1258

You should be able to "Pin" files for specific boards now.
This will help distributing those files since it will prevent them from being automatically removed by the clean up routine.

>i hate dictonaries
Wut?

I'd say go with Go.

Go's static typing helps when arguing about correctness of code which is essential if you're programming something that will have security as one of its priorities.
It is possible to use variable annotations in Python since 3.6 (see PEP 526) but you will probably be safer using something like Go that will enforce that definition of types.

Goroutines are also pretty handy and slightly more straight forward to use than Python's concurrency libs.

It's not about more than 10MB.

Anyone who needs '''more''' than 10MB can use ZeroUp.

>i don't want to download all 1Gb archives
You can use the side bar to define a limit to the size of files that will be automatically downloaded (the case where you have "help distribute all files" enabled).
You can also set that limit in the ZeroNet launcher itself.
[code]
Bigfile plugin:
  --autodownload_bigfile_size_limit MB
                        Also download bigfiles smaller than this limit if help
                        distribute option is checked (default: 1)
[/code]

==Some updates:==
1. '''bitcoinjs upgrade:''' this should noticeably increase the performance of generating new certificates.
2. '''Thumbnails for videos:''' if the browser allows it, a jpeg thumbnail will be generated while submitting a video.
If there are problems with the thumbnail generation, its thumbnail will default to the static video.png image.

>What's the deal with javascript required?
It's limitation of the current API.
The browser communicates with ZeroNet through websockets and without them there is currently no way of using most of the API endpoints.

If you have a static website that does not need to interact with the API, then it's possible to use the "/raw" prefix to make sites that do not require Javascript.

>>bf1d471c-0334-4300-8bcc-6df16560fc90
"sings" is auto-generated when you sign the file.
You can do that by dragging the "0" sidebar, then inputting "data/users/content.json" to CONTENT PUBLISHING and pressing "Sign and Publish".
After that do the same thing to content.json.
(In both cases you will probably see a "Failed to publish" error since the zite probably doesn't have any peers).

See: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:99:ZeroChat+tutorial

You may also want to change the line bellow in all.js to something else:
[code]
this.domain = "Millchan";
[/code]
Then replace all the occurrences of "millchan" in "data/users/content.json" to whatever new domain you define (all in lower case).

So if you had just copied Millchan's content.json files and signed then it would have probably been enough for it to work.

Your "cert_signers" is empty.
[code]
"cert_signers": {
  "08chan": []
}
[/code]

I don't know how you're expecting it to work like that.

If you want anonymous certificates to work it needs to have the address from the anonWIF key.
In Millchan's case, the key and address are "KxqUqNiJtKkvz5Vz4T92uZyw7n67Vvzm6Wq9nKr4RCbdDKAtrqzk" and "1NwwLdiFBcVAA4jXQ712ZtQfDHEMvk8BiD" respectively.

If you want to use a different keypair you can use bitcoinjs to generate those values then change the @anonWIF in Config and add the address to the data's content.json file.

https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/blob/master/test/integration/addresses.js#L13

==If you use a new key you will have to delete previous generated certificates from the Zeronet/data/user.json file.==

If you're unlucky it's also possible that the download has been corrupted.
There is not much you can do at this point other than deleting the file and clicking at ==[Seed]== again.

>>9311849b-25eb-4d5c-86a6-1de24f9b1808
Done. I've removed the length restriction.
Videos now will only be limited by the window's width.

It's possible you've downloaded some audio files without realizing due to the way the audio tag was being handled.
Their behavior has been changed to prevent that from happening again.

The other file formats were not affected by this problem.
Images / video thumbnails are only downloaded if they are on screen.
Other formats are only downloaded on explicit request.

The update broke a few things.
Everything should be back to normal now but there are still some CSS tweaks to be made.

Most of the components have been rewritten to use a different framework.

>custom css
Yeah, eventually.
It's not a priority though since you can easily use a browser extension to do that.

>post when outside a thread
It has been added to the todo list.

You only have pseudo-anonymity most of the time.
People may not know who you are if you're behind Tor/VPN but they can tell that the posts are being generated and signed by the same user in a given zite.

You can do it by knowing just Javascript and some SQL.
It will probably take a bit to get used to it if you don't know anything about programming / webdev.

**Also, fix your system's time otherwise all your posts will appear to have been made two months ago.**

The board owner would be able to define a list of "trusted users".
Each of those trusted users would have their own list of board related actions (mute/blacklist/etc).

When visiting a board, a user would  fetch its list of trusted users, then fetch each of their lists and, finally, filter posts that should not be displayed based on the union of all those lists.

If the board owner doesn't trust a user to moderate anymore he can just remove him from his list of trusted users.

Like it has already been mentioned in >>9f79a489-d962-4467-82e4-47ceb6327c0e ideally users would be able to completely ignore the list of any "trusted user" if they think he's doing a poor job at moderating.

>>2cf2be87-4099-4870-9536-31c669bb1351
Whether they exist or not depends on the users' '''choice''' to mute the offending users.
You, as the board owner, should '''not''' have the right to dictate what people should or shouldn't be allowed to see.

Also, the blacklist is a recommendation.
Not something that board owners should be allowed to force onto users.
If someone disabled the blacklist they probably had a reason for that and the expected behavior is displaying everything (including posts that will "dirty up" the board).

Therefore, I recommend you to focus on making the board ''clean'' to people who have the blacklist enabled instead of worrying about people who specifically went out of their way to disable it.
